nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) as advanced by Peters and collaborators is pseudoscience because it has produced few falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience
Interpretation of EE in Peters 2019: EE prescribes growth rate optimization, i.e. maximizing long run geometric average growth of wealth

Method/model used to compare EE and mainstream theory: two-asset continuous-time model where risky asset follows geometric Brownian motion dS/S = mu dt + sigma dB and investor keeps constant portfolio fraction theta, wealth follows dW/W = (r + (mu-r)theta)dt + sigma theta dB
EE prescription applied to the model: maximize time average log growth rate, which converges to r + (mu - r) theta - 1/2 sigma^2 theta^2 as T -> infinity, yielding optimal theta = (mu - r) / sigma^2

Mainstream expected utility theory (EUT) applied to the same model with CRRA utility yields objective V(theta) = r + (mu - r) theta - 1/2 gamma sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal theta = (mu - r) / (gamma sigma^2)
EE and EUT give identical prescriptions in this model only when gamma = 1 (log utility), so EE coincides with EUT only in the special logarithmic case
EE currently lacks demonstrated, nontrivial, falsifiable implications beyond special cases like log utility and the single-period growth problem
Indicator: EE makes grandiose, vague, or untestable claims such as resolving decision theory, game theory, and asset pricing without presenting concrete applications or testable implications
Indicator: EE shows improper collection or use of evidence, including citing experimental work that has been criticized and citing sources out of context

Indicator: EE shows lack of openness to testing by economics experts and limited publication in mainstream economics journals; Peters' publications are mostly outside core economics journals and include unpublished working papers

Indicator: EE displays absence of progress and reliance on old ideas (e.g., Kelly and earlier work), personalization and strongly worded critiques of established economists, and use of potentially misleading language about concepts like ergodicity and equilibrium

Counterpoint acknowledged by author: mainstream economic theory (EUT and extensions) is capable of producing testable, falsifiable implications in richer settings such as multi-period consumption-investment problems given assumptions on utility, income, and returns

Claim about EE's unfinished scope: Peters and collaborators state that generalizations beyond purely multiplicative dynamics and nonlog utilities are possible but have not been delivered in substantive form over many years

Conclusion drawn from the evidence and comparisons: until EE produces clear, testable implications and addresses the indicated issues, it should be treated with skepticism and regarded as pseudoscientific by the Popperian falsifiability criterion and common indicators of pseudoscience
